advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (May 1977) introduced the <b>System 16</b>, same as assembled System 7 with 16 Kb of RAM. ($1995)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br> To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Prior to the 6800 computer, MSI manufactured 8" floppy disc units.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"128k=2000f<br> Better know it before buying a 64k"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT MARCH 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, March 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>“Why be content with a video game system?<br> Today, the VIC-20 is available at a special price.”<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Realism goes past fiction"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HP BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract of an HP sales brochure describing the models of the HP 9000-200 series.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERTISING FOR THE SMC 70</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones for this picture.</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

computer.description:
Before Apple forced Franklin out of the desktop computer market entirely, the company released three PC compatible systems, the PC-5000 (picture), PC-6000 and PC-8000.
Both were quite similar, based on the Intel 8088. Depending on the versions, they had 512 to 640 KB of RAM, one or two 360 KB floppy drives, standard serial and parallel ports, but also built-in game port, composite video and audio outputs.
With the loss of its desktop computer business, Franklin concentrated on its handheld line, which was introduced in 1986. In the years since, Franklin has sold handheld computers that acted as personal organizers, word processors and dictionaries.
computer.keyboard: PC style with numeric keypad and 10 function keys
computer.name: PC 5000, 6000, 8000
computer.peripherals: All IBM and compatible expansion cards
computer.price: $949.99 - PC-8000 with dual FDD and video card

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-5000 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chema Matas</b> for the PC-5000 pictures</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-5000 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br><br> • Game port<br> • Parallel port<br> • Serial port<br> • Sound output<br> • Monochrome composite video output<br> • RGB video DB9 output</blockquote>
